content.title: Pulmonary Artery Catheter (Swan-Ganz)
content.summary: The pulmonary artery catheter (PAC) is a flow-directed, balloon-tipped catheter that measures right heart pressures, pulmonary artery pressures, pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP - estimate of left atrial pressure), and cardiac output via thermodilution. Once widely used, PAC use has declined significantly after RCTs showed no mortality benefit. Current indications are limited to diagnostic uncertainty in complex hemodynamic states, severe pulmonary hypertension management, and perioperative cardiac surgery monitoring.
key_points: Measures: CVP, PA pressures, PCWP, cardiac output, mixed venous O2 saturation
PCWP estimates left atrial pressure (and thus LVEDP) when balloon wedged
Thermodilution: gold standard cardiac output; cold saline injection technique
No mortality benefit in RCTs (PAC-Man, ESCAPE); use has declined dramatically
Current indications: Diagnostic uncertainty, severe pulmonary hypertension, cardiac surgery
Complications: Arrhythmias, PA rupture, infection, pulmonary infarction
content.statement: The pulmonary artery catheter provides comprehensive hemodynamic data including pressures and cardiac output, but has no proven mortality benefit and is now reserved for specific diagnostic scenarios with hemodynamic complexity.

explanation.intuition: Think of the PAC as a diagnostic journey through the right heart. It floats through the right atrium, right ventricle, and into the pulmonary artery, measuring pressures at each stop. When you inflate the balloon and 'wedge' it, you're looking backwards through the pulmonary circulation at the left atrium.
explanation.key_insight: The PCWP is the key measurement unique to the PAC. When the balloon wedges in a PA branch, forward flow stops, and the pressure measured reflects downstream left atrial pressure. This helps distinguish cardiogenic (high PCWP) from non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema (normal PCWP).
explanation.technical_details: Flow-directed insertion via central vein. Waveform progression: RA (low, venous pattern) → RV (high systolic, low diastolic) → PA (high systolic, elevated diastolic) → PCWP (low, a and v waves). Thermodilution CO: inject cold saline, measure temperature change downstream. CO = volume/area under curve.

definitions_glossary.pulmonary_artery_catheter: PAC; Swan-Ganz catheter; flow-directed catheter for hemodynamic monitoring
definitions_glossary.PCWP: Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure; estimates left atrial pressure
definitions_glossary.thermodilution: Gold standard method for cardiac output measurement
definitions_glossary.cardiac_output: CO; volume of blood pumped per minute (L/min)
definitions_glossary.cardiac_index: CO normalized to body surface area (L/min/m²)
definitions_glossary.mixed_venous_oxygen: SvO2; oxygen saturation in PA; reflects tissue oxygen extraction
definitions_glossary.CVP: Central venous pressure; right atrial pressure
definitions_glossary.PA_pressure: Pulmonary artery pressure; elevated in pulmonary hypertension
definitions_glossary.systemic_vascular_resistance: SVR; calculated from CO and pressure gradient
definitions_glossary.pulmonary_vascular_resistance: PVR; calculated from PA pressures and PCWP
definitions_glossary.hemodynamic_profile: Pattern of pressures distinguishing shock types
definitions_glossary.a_wave: Atrial contraction wave on wedge tracing

current_indications.diagnostic_uncertainty: Complex shock when noninvasive monitoring insufficient
current_indications.pulmonary_hypertension: Diagnosis and management of severe PH; vasoreactivity testing
current_indications.heart_failure: Assessment when diagnosis unclear; guide diuresis/inotropes
current_indications.cardiogenic_vs_distributive: Distinguish cardiogenic (high PCWP, low CO) from septic shock (low PCWP, high CO)

mixed_venous_O2.low: Inadequate oxygen delivery (low CO, anemia, hypoxemia)
mixed_venous_O2.high: Impaired tissue extraction (sepsis, cyanide) or shunt

positioning.tip: In main PA or large branch
positioning.wedge: Balloon inflated to obtain PCWP; deflate immediately after
positioning.CXR: Confirm position; tip should not extend past hilar shadows

PAC_Man_trial.finding: No mortality benefit in ICU patients

ESCAPE_trial.finding: No benefit over clinical assessment in heart failure

evidence.current_status: Use declined >60% since 1990s; reserved for specific scenarios

complications.arrhythmias: VT/VF during insertion or RV irritation

PA_rupture.risk: Rare but often fatal; avoid overwedging

alternatives.pulse_contour_analysis: FloTrac, PiCCO - less invasive CO monitoring

definition.@value: Flow-directed catheter for measuring right heart and pulmonary artery pressures, PCWP, and cardiac output

scopeNote.@value: Use has declined after RCTs showed no mortality benefit; reserved for diagnostic complexity

learning_objectives: Identify appropriate indications for PAC use
clinical_pearls: PCWP reflects LA pressure; high in cardiogenic, normal in septic shock
Waveform progression: RA → RV (high systolic) → PA → PCWP
No mortality benefit in RCTs - use has declined significantly
Overwedging can cause PA rupture - deflate balloon immediately after reading
Low SvO2 (<65%) indicates inadequate O2 delivery
common_misconceptions: PAC improves outcomes - RCTs show no mortality benefit
All ICU patients need PAC - less invasive alternatives often sufficient
PCWP always reflects LV filling - not accurate in mitral stenosis, pulmonary disease

citations.authors: Harvey S, Harrison DA, Singer M, et al.
citations.title: Assessment of the clinical effectiveness of pulmonary artery catheters in management of patients in intensive care (PAC-Man)

evidence.confidence_rationale: High-quality RCT evidence informs current limited use

sources.source: Marino's The ICU Book, 4th ed. Wolters Kluwer, 2014.
